awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Understanding of SEI Effects on Li Dendrite Formation and Growth
awd_abstract_narration:
Lithium ion batteries are the state-of-the-art choice for powering today's electric and hybrid electric vehicles. The energy density and power capability are limited; new chemistries are needed to increase the performance of the electric vehicle. Replacing the graphite electrodes in the commercialized lithium-ion batteries with lithium metal is expected to boost the energy density of batteries significantly. However, research efforts to use lithium metal electrodes in batteries have failed due to non-uniform deposition of lithium metal during charge and discharge cycles. This project will utilize several state-of-the art computer simulation tools and real-time microscopy techniques to investigate the lithium metal deposition in various battery electrolytes. In particular, the project will address how the by-products of electrolyte reactions with lithium metal affect the growth and morphology of lithium dendrites. The formation of these filaments in the battery shorts the battery causing failure. The results of this project will pave the road for developing high energy density lithium metal batteries. Several venues for integrating research with undergraduate and graduate education and outreach activities at University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) will occur as a result of this project. Graduate and undergraduate students will be exposed to several advanced microscopy tools and computer simulation packages that will provide a unique set of research experience. Outreach activities are planned to disseminate the results of this study to high school and undergraduate students and motivate them to pursue studies related to electrochemical energy storage technologies. Outreach activities for local high school female and underrepresented students in STEM during the UIC-Mechanical and Industrial Engineering Department Open House and UIC Summer Youth Program will be conducted. 

Lithium-metal electrodes have the potential to enable lightweight and high energy density batteries for transportation propulsion applications. A major obstacle to achieve this goal remains on the non-uniform deposition of lithium metals that appear in the form of fibrous or dendritic morphology. These lithium dendrites can poke through the electrolyte and separator of batteries and eventually result in electrical short circuit potentially causing fire. Significant research has been conducted to develop prevention mechanisms of Li dendrite growth; however, the progress has been limited due to the lack of fundamental understanding on the formation and growth of the dendrites. The fundamental questions such as how Li dendrites are formed, grown and split under the influence of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) remain unanswered. The PIs will employ a multi-scale and multi-physics approach using advance experimental and theoretical methods such as in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM), in-operando optical microscopy, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), density functional theory (DFT) calculations, and phase-field modeling (PFM) to study the growth of Li dendrites under the SEI influence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project has made substantial advancements in understanding and mitigating the mechanisms that drive battery degradation and thermal runaway (TR) in lithium-ion and lithium-metal batteries (LIBs/LMBs). Through a combined experimental and computational approach, we explored the properties and stability of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) in lithium batteries, a critical layer affecting ion transport, dendrite formation, and overall battery safety. Utilizing high-resolution techniques such as cryogenic transmission electron microscopy (Cryo-HRTEM) and density functional theory (DFT), we identified that lithium diffusion primarily occurs along grain boundaries (GBs) in SEI components like Li2O, LiF, and Li2CO3. This insight is pivotal, as it uncovers the influence of SEI structure on lithium-ion transport and dendrite nucleation, directly impacting the durability and safety of advanced battery systems.

A significant outcome of this research was the development of an integrated multiphysics model coupled with machine learning (ML) techniques to predict and prevent TR events in cylindrical Li-ion cells. By training convolutional neural networks on thermal imaging data, the model categorizes TR progression into distinct safety stages, allowing early intervention. Additionally, object detection algorithms within the ML framework identify precise heat sources, further enhancing battery safety measures. This advanced predictive model represents a powerful tool for real-time TR management, potentially informing future battery management systems (BMS) for a range of high-performance applications.

To improve the durability and safety of LMBs, we synthesized and characterized solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) incorporating multi-element oxide fillers and phosphazene-modified SEI layers. These innovations in electrolyte design effectively reduce overpotential, enhance ion conductivity, and limit dendrite growth. The project demonstrated that these SPE formulations could support stable cycling performance, making them promising candidates for high-energy-density batteries with improved safety and reliability.

In a parallel effort, we designed shape-memory polymer electrolytes that not only withstand mechanical deformation but also recover their form under thermal conditions. This research opens new directions for flexible and wear-resistant battery technologies, paving the way for applications that require adaptable, resilient energy storage solutions.

Overall, this project has contributed to both fundamental and applied research in battery science, particularly by addressing the critical issues of thermal runaway, dendrite suppression, and electrolyte stability, thus supporting the next generation of safe, high-performance energy storage systems.

This project’s outcomes have fostered educational and societal benefits, especially in training future engineers and scientists in cutting-edge battery technologies. Research insights were incorporated into the existing curricula, where students engaged in practical applications of modeling and safety prediction for Li-ion and Li-metal batteries. This integration provided hands-on experience with advanced HRTEM, multiphysics and ML models, preparing students for careers in battery science and energy management.

 


Last Modified: 11/09/2024
Modified by: Farzad Mashayek

Image
  • Schematic illustration of physics informed ML study to predict and identify the TR in cylindrical type LIBs. The multiphysics modeling (left-hand side image, not to scale) of cylindrical battery is used to create a data set for ML (middle image), allowing to identify and forecast the TR in LIBs.
    PIs
    Public Domain
    Farzad Mashayek
    Thermal Runaway Prediction
